channel.title: Comments on: ASP.Net – Ensure your Actions aren’t missing Authorization with Unit Tests
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.dc:creator: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.description:
Absolutely. I have a fairly large project with a range of tests like these to ensure all of the endpoints have authorization defined, error handling, logging, etc. If you had specific rules around caching (only use 10 minute or something like that), you could use it to detect inconsistent usage of that as well.
That's a good point on the effect of the cache attribute.

item.title: By: Saeid
item.dc:creator: Saeid
item.description: Another test can be detecting action methods that have both caching and authorization at the same time. When an action method is cached, authorization won't be called anymore.
item.content:encoded: Another test can be detecting action methods that have both caching and authorization at the same time. When an action method is cached, authorization won’t be called anymore.
